Carvings seem in excellent condition and may have been restored. Walk and explore in relative quiet as visitors here are less. Enjoyed our visit and took loads of photos.

Nice Temple. It's a nice temple but quite far. There are a lot of better temple near the city. Plus, beware of the vendors selling souvenir items. They will not let you go when you try to ask for price. They can also get rude sometimes.

A not to be missed temple. If you're headed out to Banteay Srei, then don't miss Banteay Samre. It's a nice little temple that is worth a visit because of its uniqueness. One of the great things is that it's generally not overrun with tourists.While you're there, take some time in the village nearby, Prey Dak, It's a great place to enjoy traditional Cambodian noodles in the morning, shop for baskets and other handicrafts, or watch them make palm sugar.

Part of a long day. If you are getting tired and want to miss some temples you could omit this one. Still interesting but nothing over and above many of the other temples. Worth doing if you still have energy and determination!

loved this. this was a wonderful contrast to angkor wat--not that there was anything wrong with angkor wat!the sandstone was an interesting difference, and the intricacy of design of the sandstone itself was fascinating.

A smaller temple which we saw on our way back to Siem Reap. A smaller temple which we saw on our way back to Siem Reap after visiting Banteay Srei and Kbal Spean. Not many tourists. As with other temples good carvings and interesting structures. Go with a guide and take hat and water.
Cycling. Cycling pass big circle Angkor areathrough to Banteay Samre.It's a pair of Banteay Srey.Compare both difference design but both are small small temple.Not many tourist there as Banteay Srey.
Bantay Srei. Once a beautiful temple now it's dying but behind the ruins , one can see how beautiful it was once.

Picture Perfect. Out of all the buildings and temple structures, think my perfect shots were at Banteay Samre. Here again, the buildings were awesome and will come alive when the guide starts explaining the course of nature that took place.

One of the nicest temples in Angkor Wat. The Banteay Samre was for me one of the nicest temples in Angkor Wat.The artwork is amazing.It's more special than Ta Prohm or some other famous temples.Don't miss it!

Like buried treasure. Banteay Samre was my second favourite of all the temples I visited in Angkor park. In my opinion it is more special even than Ta Prohm and Angkor Wat itself. There is a beautiful energy in the complex and, while smaller than some of the other temples, the carving is so beautiful that it really is a wonderful place to visit. Best of all it's not as popular as other temples so you may find yourself nearly alone here.Well worth a visit. Make the effort and you will be rewarded :)

An out of the way gem. we were tired by the time we got to this temple. But it was worth it. We did our usual wander round, and then as we were leaving we found some very interesting "unfinished" carving ariund the widow openings. It gave us a fantastic insight into the process of the carving as you could see just where they "stopped"
If you are in the area. This is a nice temple but it cannot be compared to the most famous ones. If you are visiting with a tuk tuk, it may not be worth the trip as it is a little out of town.

A grey temple. Some of the photos posted by previous reviewers are for Banteay Srei (which is not far from this temple); not for Banteay Samre. Do those people even know where they went? When we visited this temple, it was not crowded (hardly anyone else). See attached photos (no one else in sight). We enjoyed the drive from Siem Reap to this area.

great place. nice place where you will see ancient ruin,,i am sure u would enjoy there especially for those who like taking picsdon't forget bring your umbrella,, it is open area and the sunny and rainy weather over the year
small but powerfull. i like the idea to have small but strong concept :)should come and see it only for 2 hour round trip will be enough

Beautiful temple. A visit to Banteay Samre can be combined with an excursion to Banteay Srei, which it should precede if possible. The whole trip takes perhaps 2 hours and is best made in the morning.

Little Angkor Wat. Don't mix Banteay Srei (the one with the pink-ish coloured stones) with Banteay Samre. Banteay Samre is known as the little Angkor Wat, because is just as beautiful and well preserved. You will need a tuk-tuk to get there, but it is worth it. There are toilet and eating facilities just outside the entrance of this temple and not many people come here, so it is a real treat.We had a great tuk-tuk driver in Siem Reap, so if you need one, you can find him just outside the Tara Angkor Hotel (On the road to Angkor Wat) his name is Rado Doung and he drives tuk-tuk number 5. He will take you to this temple and all the others.

An oasis of peace - a miniaure of Angkor Wat. Banteay Samre is one of the best preserved temples on the Angkor circuit, but it is surprisingly little visited. In consequence, it is one of the best temples to choose for a visit.There is no visitors' centre or other facilities, and the temple itself is rather isolated.It has often been described as Angkor Wat in miniature, as it shares so many distinctive architectural features with Angkor Wat (especially the lotus tower), but for me the real attraction of Banteay Samre is in the detail: there are numerous fine flourishes and miniature carvings on lintels and pillars to be discovered. The peaceful atmosphere of this temple also lets you imagine how it was 500 years ago, with a community and a daily ritual.
Very nice. Very nice structure with not so big size like other temples. Have a good time to tour thru.It locates remote to other circled temples but really worth visiting

Best of the ruins. After Angkor Wat, Angkor Tom etc., etc., I thought I had seen all the old ruined temples I wanted to see. What a pleasant suprise to find that Banteay Samre was something a bit different and interesting. And, we enjoyed to drive through the coutryside to get there.

Excellent temple - great condition. I went here in the afternoon and it was so lovely.the inner courtyard was in really good condition and it was such a lovely place.I highly recommend as a combination going to Bantey Srei and the landmine Museum.Its a good hike if you add the other two attractions so for this day we hired a car instead of a tuk tuk and we were so glad

Banteay Samre. Stopped here after visiting Banteay Srey. Quite large and mostly flat temple with towers similar to those of Angkor Wat. The carvings are still in very good condition and photograph well.
a beautiful, smaller scale temple. This temple is smaller than most of the Angkor temples, with intricate stone carvings. It was my favourite Angkor temple.

One of my favorites!. Banteay Samre is a very beautiful 12th century Hindu Temple that was constructed around the same time as Angkor Wat with similar style architecture.Banteay Samre is also known as the Child of Angkor Wat and it is a bit off the normal tourist track but is definitely worth the effort to visit here as there are many carvings that are in excellent condition, well preserved buildings and very quiet, not many tourists at all. I actually liked it a lot more than Banteay Srey. Combine a visit here with a stop at Banteay Srey; the trip is lovely passing through villages and rice paddies.

Banteay Samre. Our 2nd spots to visit at Angkor on our 1st day in Siem Reap. Facinating. Taken quite a number of photos and stayed for about half an hour to appreciate the carving on the stones. Great job of the people in the 12th century.

Wonderful. 5th out of 6 temples visited on the Outlying Adventure Tour with Beyond Unique Escapes. Beautiful temple with gorgeous carvings, constructed around the same time as Angkor Wat. Would never had seen this temple if we hadn't done tour as its a little bit out of the way, well worth a visit.

See with Banteay Srei. A smaller temple which we saw on our way back to Siem Reap after visiting Banteay Srei and Kbal Spean. Not many tourists. As with other temples good carvings and interesting structures. Go with a guide and take hat and water.
Peaceful setting. Much of the protective wall has been restored. Interesting to speculate on what the pillars originally held up. Distinctive carvings.

A Good, Relatively Small, Introductuion to the Angkor Complex. We visited this temple and found it quite accessible. There was almost no one here, and that was a notable plus. You could see the type of stones used and the style of construction that could be found in perhaps parts of the various other structures in the overall Angkor temple complex. What was interesting was the window areas that had what looked to be circular, intricately-carved, stone columns or poles, placed within the open part, that supported them. There could be four or more of them within each opening, seeming to provide support for the parts of the temple above the openings. The carving designs, all in circular patterns, may show that they were first cut and then rotated in some fashion to allow the carvers to produce what I though were really interesting circular patterns. Parts were thicker, other parts thinner, in what gave a sense of how advanced these artisans were with the tools they had to design and execute such items.An aside - walking to a nearby restroom after visiting Bante Samre, I came upon a huge spider web with a huge spider on it. Black, white, red, and yellow, with some stripes - I'd never seem anything like it. It was just off the trail, so easy to see and get to.
an interesting temple. worth seeing on the trip to Bantey seri. It is different again and has an interesting floor plan. It is more compact and not too time consuming.

Worth a visit. Quite interesting structure with some nice carvings. This was worth a visit because it is quieter and less visited than other temples. This allows you to soak up the atmosphere and really see the structures

Amazingly intact!. This was one of our favourite temples, not too crowded, a bit off the beaten path. The buildings have been restored, sort of reminds you of a cloistered abbey! But with the Angkor style stone, and the heavy barrel roofs. We hired a taxi for two days travel to the Angkor complexes, more expensive than a Tuk Tuk, The third day had a tuk tuk, to the Rolios group. Saw more of the scenery fron the tuk tuk!
One of the top 10 tempes to visit. Not at all as crowded as the main temples, but a beauty in its own right. When you have a few hours to spare, include this one in your itinerary

Worth a visit if you are going to Bantey Srei. This is a smaller temple but well worth the visit on the way to Bantey srei. The architecture is similar to Bantey srei but not as delicate.We went in the morning and it was not very crowded since the tours were on their way to Bantey srei.

An average temple. Nothing to much to see here,but if your temple touring and its part of your route go for it.A few interesting carvings.Half an hour is plenty enough here.Part of Angkor ticket price.

Similar to Angkor Wat, Less Visited, Well Worth It. The most memorable part was the long pathway leading up to the outer gate of the temple and the large most/river in front where kids were playing in a boat. Beautiful and a bit more removed from the more touristy temples. I liked the grass growing in the temple grounds and the various levels that you can climb up and down. The only thing that ruined my time here was a group of Russians who shoved me told me to "get out of the way" so they could take a picture. Seriously? Calm down Russkies.

Not very visited, I don't know why. There was hardly anyone here and I don't understand why as it was my favorite temple. There is a huge promenade around the whole thing you can walk around and see. Then there are several temples on different levels you can explore, it's nice that you can climb around to discover the place.

B. Samre... take out the photos of Bantaey Srei about 12-15 of them. it was most disappointing to see the photos of bantaey srei among the 71 you show..I think accuracy and credibility is important. I usually visit B. Samre about 40 times a year as I have some good friends working there. I have visited to Siem Reap 3 times in 2011 and 3 times in 2012 and stay a month each time and I'm going in 4 days fo another 15 visits to B. Samre
Flat and good. Enjoyed this temple. Pleasant surprise with it being flat, so not heaps of steep stairs like some of them.
Another Must See. Simply beautiful and a must go as well, its not far from Bantey Srei, so you might as well go to this temple as well.

Peaceful Temple. My friend and I went to Banteay Samre on the way back from banteay Srei. There were not a lot of people visiting this out of the way temple which made it less crowded and peaceful. If you've seen the other temples in Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom, you'd be seeing more of the same here but nonetheless its still worth visiting simply because there are not a lot of people going here.

Spiritual Banteay Samre. We visited Banteay Samre on the way back from Santeay Srei. We got there about 10h00 and not many visitors so this was great as it gave us time to explore the temple at a good pace. We felt that of all the temples, Banteay Samre had a serene and spiritual feel to it. Not sure if this is because it was not as crowded.

One of my favorite stops. It was a bit of a drive, but this temple was a little less busy and was very nice to see. There is almost no climbing on this tour, which was a nice change!The color and small details on this temple were amazing.There was a band playing at the end of the temple, and we sat and listened to a song and made a donation.On the long walk back to the front of the temple, we were grabbed by an older lady who wanted money and a younger man later who might have been with her. It was not violent in any way, but the rural setting of this area and fewer travelers may have made this more likely.I don't recommend visiting the shops here -- it was even worse than normal and I didn't see anything different than I'd seen in town.

Felt like Indian Jones. This was not part of my tour but our guide was able to setup a driver to take us out there on our last morning in Siem Reap. It is a very long drive out of town 60 - 90 minutes but well worth the trip and I think a must see. We got there early enough that the place was not crowded and as I approached the ruins I felt like I was Indian Jones discovering some new ruined temple in my quest for some lost artifact. Unlike the places closer to Siem Reap this place has not been restored and only in a few places will you find wooden walk ways or support structures where it is too dangerous to do with out. This means lots of ducking in under low fallen stones or climbing up piles of ruble as you explore and nothing is off limits (though some places were hard to get to). We picked up a guide at the entrance, a Khmar woman around mid to lat 30s with a wooden leg which may have been the result of a land mine. She led us through showing us various things and pointing out interesting parts of the ruins and I think we paid her about 10 or 20 USD at the end, well worth it.Unfortunatly our time was limited as we had a flight to catch so I would recommend dedicating a day to this and maybe some of the surrounding areas.I will try to post some pictures later.erik
Another great temple. Similar to Angkor Watt on a much smaller scale, but well worth a visit. Internal moat but no water when we were there.

Worth the visit. It's one of the lesser visited wat's. It is small in size but still very interesting as the carvings are much finer than Angkor Wat. So you actually get time to take some great photos without a tourist in sight

Great and less touristy. Great temple because its quiet and just off the main routes. Has been really well restored and has slightly different architecture to some of the others include great terraces on one of the sides.

Angkor Wat in miniature. Lovely calm atmosphere, prob about 5 miles from Angkor Wat but I would guess, little visited as we had the site almost to ourselves, fine, elaborate carving, well preserved, not to be missed.
A smaller temple but well worth a visit. If you are travelling out to Banteay Srei, make sure you visit Samre on the way. Quality over quantity.

Small temple, less frequently visited. This is a nice temple in good condition. It doesn't take long to walk around, but it has some great long corridors and stone work, and far fewer people than most other temples.
Peaceful temple. Somewhat off the beaten track this is an interesting temple that attracts relatively few visitiors so it is a pleasure to discover.

Incredible carvings. The most detailed carvings are to be found on the pink sandstone encased temple. It has been roped off to protect the carvings, which makes it feel more distant and not as up close and personal as it was in earlier years, but still a marvel to behold. Smaller and easy to navigate, but a bit of a drive from Siem Reap and most of the Angkor complex but worth it if you have time, which you should make for this awesome place.
Restored. This place was a welcomed visit, a restored temple and barely a crowd. We would certainly recommend this temple.
Enchanting.... This is near Banteay Srei. Less crowd but a must see temple list in siem reap. Carvings are also amazing. Easy to take photos since not much crowd here.

Great Temple without the Crowds. Banteay Samre was one of my favorite temples visited during my tour of the Angkor Temples. The temple itself is amazing in terms of carvings and detail, but what made it different from the other temples was the somewhat remote location. Whereas most of the other temples had swarms of visitors, Banteay Samre was relatively deserted when we visited. It really gave that sense of discovery that we search for. Also allowed for some great photographs without having to wait for other people to move out of the way. One of the better temples to visit among the Angkor complex.

one of the favourites. This temple is close to Siem Reap, but just off the Grand Circuit making it less popular with the crowds which is perhaps one of its best features.It has been restored to very good condition, is easy to navigate and has lots of interesting 'nooks & crannies' (excuse the technical talk here). There are some great carvings and towers in a similar style to those at Angkor Wat.We visited early afternoon and despite being a very hot & humid day it seemed to have lots of cool spots to escape the sun. All of these things would put it in my top 3 of about 15 temples that I visited.

Diminishing returns. The Siem Reap area is an embarrassment of riches. This temple, were it located anywhere else, would be a must see. But although it's not, strictly speaking, very far away, you also don't get more than about 20-30 km an hour out here on a tuk tuk). So if you've only got 2-3 days here, you probably want to budget your time carefully. This is simply not as memorable as the top 7 or 8 sites in the Angkor area, including Bantei Srei, which is indeed worth a visit. Do the big route and the small route first. If you have more than 3 days, absolutely make it out here. But if you don't, you may regret not having had those two extra hours to see one of those temples that really caught your fancy one last time.

Small and calm ruins. Compared to Angkor Wat, there are not so many tourists around here so you can chill out.The original ruins without much renovation attract you.On the other hand, little renovation makes your feet sort of burden.

Real ruins!. When we visit Angkor Wat, people say we are visiting ruins. But if you are really interested in seeing temple ruins, visit Bantey Samre. A massive renovation is under progress and it feels good that governments from all over the world like France & India with UN are supporting this renovations to save one of the oldest sites of this world. These temples are very close to Bayon and main Angkor temples. A little bit of imagination can do wonders and can surely take you to th at era.

Try not to miss this temple. It is hard to decide which temples to visit if you only have a few days (that is why you should try to stay in Siem Reap for at least 5 days), but try not to miss this temple. It has important carvings and it is very beautiful. It can be visited easily on your way back from Banteay Srei, and because it is not very big it will not take too long.

Hardly any visitors. This temple seems small and when I was there only one other visitor was around. It was actually a bit sad. I find the place quite beautiful and the carvings are still quite beautiful.

Peaceful and well restored. The temple is a little off the standard round - about 3 km east of the East Mebon. This means that you stand a good chance of having it to yourself.The impressive surrounding wall is about 6m high. The gopuras have some good deep relief carvings of scenes from the Ramayana. There are more relatively well preserved carvings on the lintels and pediments of the inner enclosure surrounding the single tower.

Not worth the time. When we went here,we were surprised that the ruins are too smalls.We spend much time to visit here,but no amazing and we think Angkor wat is enough.There are many ruins in Siem Reap,but almost ruins are similar and we cannot visit all ruins.You should think and go where you really want to go.

My favourite temple. This is a little off the beaten track and when we arrived there we had the place to ourselves. As well as the temple building there is an impressive terrace outside with an elevated walkway leading off into the jungle ... I wondered what it led to when the temple was in use. This is a special and serene place.

Too short time. We did not have enough time to visit this temple to its full extend, but were there long enough to experience the intimacy that is created through the fact that the temple has two moats (as the only one in Angkor). It closes at 5pm (we thought at 6pm, hence why we were late)

Overlooked gem. This place is gorgeous. It's off the beaten track and very quiet so you can appreciate it in peace. It's smaller than the well-known temples, but with beautiful carvings that are very deep and relatively well-preserved.

Much quiter, time to explore. This was also a great temple. It is a lot quiter than the others and you can get around and explore everything. It also has been damaged from the war as our guide tolds the vietnamese hid here. There are many little girls trying to sell you things as you walk in, although these are quite clever as they get your name and remember you as you walk out!This temple should definitely be on your list.

My favourite temple. This temple is just amaizing.Is a small temple but ho boy is it good! is on the middle of nowhere and you have to walk a bit to get there but really worth it.the whole temple is complete so no rocks in the floor and if it looks so good now imagine 800 years ago.get there early in the morning 8am -8:30am and you will have some of the best photos of your holidays.

Smaller and less crowded. If you are out this way, this stop is a must. It was part of our tour package so we had a driver and tour guide the whole day. The guide was very knowledgeable and had good insights as to what we were seeing. A lot less crowded so able to get some great pics with no one in them. Annoying that the hawkers - a of of kids - latch themselves onto you as soon as you exit the car and when you return. How many times do I have to say "no thank you" before it gets old and I get angry...

beautiful carvings. Most people go to angkor wat, bayon and ta phrom, 3 of the more popular temples. But if you have time, try going to some of the other temples like banteay samre and banteay srey. The carvings and bas relief are more intact and so detailed, you can spend hours just looking at them. Also, because banteay samre is less known, you get more chances for photo-ops.

Another amazing site. This is another temple at Angkor, located east of Baray built under Suryavarman the 2nd and Yasovarman the 2nd in the early 12th century it is a hindu temple in the Angkor Wat style named after Samre an ancient people of Indochina, it also uses the same stone as Banteay Srei

Nice temple. Banteay Samre is a little far away from Angkor and can best be visited using a taxi. A Tuktuk would be more romantic but would probably take more than 1/2 an hour. Nice temple but for us not as interesting as for instance Ta Prohm or Preah Khan.

Hidden gem. Not many people make the effort to visit this temple that's a little out of the way & that's the magic of this temple - uncrowded. Worth a stop if you happen to be heading out to Banteay Srei.

Small Temple - Big on Character and Color. This was one of the most beautiful temples with the colored stone and carvings! It was fascinating to walk thru! Take a picture inside the "picture frame" temple door!
Miniature of Angkor Wat. To me, this temple is just like small Angkor Wat. Nice to visit in the afternoon and see sunset from the temple.

Of the track. One of the lesser visited Angkorian temple. Which allows for taking architectural picture with no tourist in the way. The temple isn't built by a King unlike others. but built by a community dedicated to a king. As such the temple is small and isn't as grand as Angkor Wat despite being built by the same people that built Angkor Wat. The base isn't made of sand stone like Angkor Wat, probably they ran out of stones or that sand stones from Kulem is expensive to get. It's less ornate compared to the pink Banteay Srei but it's complex is bigger and has it's own solitude to bolster it's charm. Come here together with the Banteay Srei tour, as it's on the same route.
Wow!. Honestly I prefer this then angkor Wat. It isSmall but full of details. A little off though.

Small but Impressive temple!. Well All I can can say is I wish I had seen this temple on my first visit. The ornateness and carvings on this temple are awe inspiring. This temple also sees less visitors so it is possible to view it almost entirely by ones self. I had only to wait 10 minutes for 2 others to leave and then had the temple to myself for about 20 minutes. The carvings remind me of the detail you find at Banteay Srei. I almost hate to write a review as this will send more visitors to this lovely temple.
Wow. Even though it is small, this is probably the best site we visited in Siem Reap
Beautiful bas reliefs abound. This quiet temple is worth visiting. You can admire the bas reliefs in peace and quiet, away from the crowds of the top rated temples.
Well worth visit. This place is well worth the visit! just mind your step....

A lovely experience. This temple, along with Banteay Srei and a handful of others make up the "grand tour" as is the local jargon among guesthouses and drivers. If you're going on any part of the grand tour, you might as well see Banteay Samre. It is a pleasant temple, free of the myriad of tourists who flock to the main Angkor attractions located toward the center of the complex. I particularly enjoyed strolling around unmolested by peddlers and monks selling either goods or blessings. In fact, I've had a lovely conversation with a monk there and decided to get a blessing after all. The whole experience was lovely.

Off the beaten path but well worth the visit.. Slightly off the main road, Banteay Samre is a 12th century temple, beautifully restored, and well worth a look. Frangipani trees grow inside the compound making for some great photography. Passed over by the large groups, go and check it out and enjoy some solitude.
mini angkor wat. the guide said this temple is very similar to angkor wat in design...not a hard temple to visit oming from banteay srei. it is not that big and we were done in 30 min.
beautiful temple. We visited this temple after many others and it still managed to surprise us. The decorations of the walls are more detailed than in many other temples

Beautifully Restored. I like this place because the restoration easily provokes a vision of what it once was. Combine visit to Banteay Samre with Banteay Srei. While the volume of tourists flocking this temple is relatively low, I recommend being there around 8:00AM to 10:00AM if you like to take photos (without any tourists obstructing the view as with the other more popular temples).

Worth a visit. If time permits, it is worth visiting this temple which was completely restored using the anastylosis method. Tour groups tend to skip this temple so when we were there, there were perhaps no more than 8 to 10 people. There is a spiritual aura about this place -- quiet, serene, reflective -- one of our favorite temples.
Look for the meteorite .... Take your time; it's worth it. Look for the meteorite on one of its buildings, very interesting and life-like! Pleasant surprise.
Worth the trip. Its a long way to get to but well worth the trip hire a tuk tuk for the day $15 and see other sites in the area long day!
Beautifully restored temple. A well restored temple, one of the most complete for you to see. Fairly quiet here too compared to other temples closer to Angkor Wat. Make sure you don't miss it.
Banteay Samre. A beach in the middle of historic structures. Just stop by Banteay Samre when you feel hot and tired during your visit to the ancient Angkor city.

Small but impressive.. We included a trip to this temple with one to Banteay Srei. Compact and a bit out of the way, we enjoyed exploring it moreso because there were so few other people there. Well worth the detour.
Amazing. Another great temple. Quite tranquill and magical.Get around the back of the wall and there you will find an oasis

Well restored temple. We allocated one day to the temples that were a little further out (this one is only a short drive from the others) and our tuk tuk driver suggested including it and I am so glad he did. This temple has been completely restored and has a sanctuary tower in the centre. There were hardly any tourists at all there, very nice and peaceful after the masses at Angkor Wat, Ta Prohm etc. They have done such a good job with the restoration and this one was not on my list so we nearly missed it. There are two libraries and a high wall around the outside, several interesting carvings on the doorways of the inner enclosure. Great photography opportunities due to having it almost to ourselves. Include this one as its completeness make it really worth a visit.

Compact enough for exploration; a little out of the way. Banteay Samré is outside of the Grand Tour Circuit so it is slightly out of the main attractions such as Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom. If you plan to visit this temple, pair it up with a visit to Banteay Srey and possibly the Angkor Butterfly Centre, Cambodia Landmine Museum and the shooting range.It is not as small as Ta Som but I wouldn’t call it medium either. I guess the word “compact” is more appropriate. The size is about right for exploration but it should not take you more than one hour to do so. There is a short path on the left side of the temple that you can also explore.

Banteay Samre is Quite A Gem. I was there in July, during the low season, and Banteay Samre was very quiet and peaceful. There were less than 10 tourists. Definitely great to visit, as you can feel like you own this huge temple with green surroundings all to yourself. Banteay Samre is very well preserved, there was some ongoing restoration work; as with all other temples in Siem Reap.Your tuk-tuk driver will most probably drop you off at the N entrance. Following suggestion from the guidebook Ancient Angkor, I walked all the way towards the N gate, but turn left and walk along the wall until I reached E gate. Then, I backtracked to see the terrance and walkway, which has some nice sculptures of ruined lions.The temple buildings in the enclosure are quite small, compact and they stood on a platform risen from the ground floor. This makes the temple quite special. Really worth your time.

Good pictures. Did this Angkor Wat era temple on the way to Bantei Srei on the two occasions I was in Siem Reap. On both times, pictures of this temple soemhow turned out to be among the best. It is a slight walk in from the main road and is walled, with the main temple inside in quite a good state.The inner moat (with no water of course) within the temple's compound is the only one I have noticed of the Angkor temples and walking around and accross it from one wing to another was good fun. As with each different temple in the Angkor area, this too gives you a different feel. Worth a visit
